text: earnings season is coming to an end and
Wall Street to use their words is
feeling cautiously optimistic about the
economy still the results coming out of
the first quarter were decidedly mixed
which done through more than anything
this quarter is that firms like morgan
stanley and goldman sachs have finally
started to get rid of some of the issues
that have held them back in recent years
since the credit crisis for example
goldman sachs paid back the investment
that they got from warren buffett in
2008 and morgan stanley just today
announced that they plan to pay back
mitsubishi the investment that it made
these investments are coming at a cost
to the shareholders of these firms in
the case of morgan stanley it's going to
be paying two billion dollars in the
form of stock to get rid of this an
extra butt I think shareholders are
finally relieved that these firms are
moving through these issues still though
you're not seeing shareholders flocking
to this sector they're still way down by
a lot of issues be it pending regulation
you've also got excess capital that
they're hanging on to and all this is
weighing down their return on equity
they're also not dealing with as much
leverage as a result of this these
issues investors are pretty gun-shy
about these stock sale and you're seeing
some major names selling out of them and
at the other end of the spectrum you
still have some firms that are very much
weighed down by the credit crisis bank
of america is a prime example it not
only has legal costs that it's dealing
with but it had to set aside a billion
dollars related to expensive from its
countrywide acquisition at the height of
the credit crisis oh we're certainly not
back to the to the crazy days of 2006
and 2007 and new normal is starting to
emerge on Wall Street
